sub_title: Postdoc in Computational Systems Biology at Wageningen University
summary: Henk is an ambitious and independent researcher in specialized in Modeling of Biological Systems. He has strong quantitative skills and uses these skills together with his curiosity and discipline to unravel the biological mechanisms of life. He participated in the cross-disciplinary “Reduced methane emission of dairy cows” TI Food and Nutrition project team of Animal Nutritionists, Geneticists, Microbiologists and Dairy Scientists. Throughout this project, he focused on modeling of rumen fermentation physiology in cattle and predicting enteric methane emissions. Upon finishing his PhD, He spent more than 3 years at the Animal Science department at the University of California, Davis (USA). Henk currently works at the Laboratory of Systems and Synthetic Biology at Wageningen University, and is involved in the "Me, my diet and I" project. He contributes to the development of a Digital Twin for predicting personalized Glucose and Triglyceride dynamics in blood plasma for which he applies various dynamic modelling approaches. Henk's most recent publication is "Inhibited Methanogenesis in the Rumen of Cattle: Microbial Metabolism in Response to Supplemental 3-Nitrooxypropanol and Nitrate". (https://doi.org/10.3389/fmicb.2021.705613)

projects: [{'title': 'Reduced Methane Emission of Dairy Cows', 'date': {'start': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2012}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'description': 'This project aims at increasing knowledge about methane production by dairy cows in order to reduce the ecological footprint of dairy production. For this purpose, we are developing an indicator for methane emission from individual cows; we are exploring the genetic variation in methane emission between cows; we are characterizing the composition and functioning of microorganisms in the rumen of the cow; and we are developing mechanistic models to improve the understanding of how methane emission is influenced by the interaction between the genetics of the cow, the microorganisms in the rumen of the cow and cow feedstuffs.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Henk', 'last_name': 'van Lingen',
